message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The lumbar puncture needle passes through several layers of tissue before entering the epidural space, including the skin, subcutaneous fat, superficial fascia, deep fascia, and ligamentum flavum. The resistance just before entering the epidural space suggests that the needle encountered the ligamentum flavum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The resistance just before entering the epidural space suggests the needle has encountered the ligamentum flavum, which serves as one of the ligaments that connect adjacent laminae of the vertebral column.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The resistance felt is most likely due to the ligamentum flavum, which is a dense ligament that connects the adjacent vertebrae and forms the posterior border of the spinal canal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The resistance is most likely due to the ligamentum flavum, which is a thick ligament that covers the epidural space and helps support the spinal column. The other options are not located in close proximity to the epidural space and would not cause resistance during a lumbar puncture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The resistance just before entering the epidural space is most likely due to the ligamentum flavum, which serves as a barrier between the epidural space and the spinal canal. The other options are not located in this area and would not cause resistance during a lumbar puncture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The resistance just before entering the epidural space is most likely due to the ligamentum flavum, which is a layer of yellow elastic tissue that connects the laminae of adjacent vertebrae. It forms the posterior wall of the vertebral canal and is an important anatomical marker during lumbar puncture procedures.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The question asks about a structure that causes resistance during lumbar puncture. Among the options, only the ligamentum flavum is a thick ligament that covers the epidural space, so it is the most likely structure that would cause resistance. The other options are not located at the site of the epidural space.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ligamentum flavum is a ligament that connects adjacent vertebral laminae, and it forms the posterior boundary of the spinal canal. Resistance just before entering the epidural space suggests the needle encountered this ligamentum flavum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The resistance just before entering the epidural space is most likely due to the ligamentum flavum, which thickens and forms a barrier to the needle. The other options are not located in the same area and would not cause resistance during a lumbar puncture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The resistance just before entering the epidural space is likely due to the ligamentum flavum, which is a thick ligament that forms the roof of the spinal canal. Its role is to connect and support the laminae of adjacent vertebrae.
